destination.label: Marrakech
destination.title: Marrakech The Red City, where anything is possible

content.intro:
Displaying ochre façades, this beautiful city relies on a troubled past to roll out a fabulous heritage, in the shade of historic riads.

It took almost a millennium to build the city, in turns capital of an empire and residence of sultans, caliphs and kings, yet commercial and cultural metropolis since always. A thousand years and several dynasties helped shape the multiple faces of Marrakech.
Fourth largest city in Morocco, it has always leant on craftsmanship and trade. Today, it stills grows due to the exponential dividends of tourism. Culture, arts and singular architectural heritage spread all over town. It is located 80 kilometres (50 miles) from the High Atlas mountain range, a majestic natural site where you can practice many activities. From downhill skiing to bivouacking in the Agafay mineral desert, which offers white dunes of rocks, there is something for everyone. Closer to the High Walls, you may prefer windsurfing on an oasis (at Lake Lalla Takerkoust) or golfing for an entire round in the city, in the steps of Winston Churchill.
You have multiple choices of activities in Marrakech, from wandering through the souks to visiting Saadian tombs (which steles are made of cedar woof and stucco). You can also recharge your batteries in the poetic blue hues of the Majorelle Garden, discover a madrasa (Koranic University dating back to the 16th century) which displays wonders of Arabic and Andalusian architecture. To get some rest, hotels amidst the Palmeraie offer surprising design.
At the level of the tall Koutoubia minaret, you will love strolling in the palaces. Their gardens house olive and orange groves, as well as plants of diverse varieties and scents. Wander around the different neighbourhoods in town, from the terraces of cafés to restaurants offering Moroccan, French and fusion cuisines, before immersing yourself in the warm nights of the Hivernage district.
Since the late 1960s, Marrakech has become a privileged spot for the jet-set, soon adopted by Yves Saint-Laurent. Armed with fabulous riads amidst the Medina, golf courses and universities, it now also offers a film festival, a contemporary art fair and a private campus. Since always, it has been known for its high quality craftsmanship, blazing colours, lively music and spellbinding fragrances.

localCalendar.title: FESTIVALS, HOLIDAYS AND OTHER ANNUAL EVENTS IN Marrakech

content.title: +61: an Australian chef with Italian inspirations

introduction.small: Here, Australian minimalism meets Mediterranean flavours for a gourmet break, far from the bustle and eccentricity Marrakech is known for.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: +61: an Australian chef with Italian inspirations

paragraphs.text:
As a result of the fusion between Australian-born Cassandra Karinsky and Sébastian de Gzell, owner of the famous Nomad Café, +61 opened in Guéliz, Marrakech's westerner and modern neighbourhood. Looking like a retro canteen, the restaurant displays pastel tones and urges patrons to discover delicious dishes to share. Opened all week for lunch (except on Sunday) and two nights per week, it is the perfect location for a lunch among friends. The restaurant offers homemade cooking, prepared with organic products carefully selected from local farmers.

On the menu: burrata, malloreddus (small Sardinian gnocchi), roast chicken and polenta cake all witness to the Italian inspirations of Australian chef Andrew Cibej. Quality is infallible and the menu changes regularly, according to available seasonal products.

+61
96, rue Mohammed el Beqal
Guéliz
Marrakech 4000

+212 5 24 20 70 20

www.plus61.com

Menu : around 235 MAD

content.title: Desert utopia with Terre des étoiles

introduction.small: Terre des étoiles is an oasis created 25 km from Marrakech, in the midst of Agafay's arid desert; where life takes on a special meaning, all the more than it is rare.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Desert utopia with Terre des étoiles

paragraphs.text:
In order to ensure success of his high-class camp, owner Pierre-Yves Marais chose to push ecotourism forward. Here, all products are farmed around you, with no intermediary between the garden and your plate.

In the oasis, you will stay in large tents, halfway between, traditional Berber habitats and the lodges of Southern Africa, guarantees of unique and very comfortable nights. You will discover an autonomous and self-sufficient universe that includes permaculture, ecological building, solar panels and water supplies to deliver a smooth experience.

Entertainment on site is diversified, with meditating and yoga sessions, camel rides and visits of nearby Berber villages. Do not miss the astronomy night, during which the exceptional clarity of the skies allows you to observe the stars over the Agafay desert.

Terres des étoiles
12 Derb El baroud
Marrakech, 40000

+ 212 (0)5 24 44 73 75

www.terredesetoiles.co.uk/en/

Around 1,700 MAD

content.title: Colourful break at Bakchich Café

introduction.small: Dressed in warm and bright colours, Bakchich Café is an unexpected spot for coffee, juice and even lunch.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Colourful break at Bakchich Café

paragraphs.text:
Only a few steps away from the Jeema-el-Fnaa square in the heart of Marrakech, Bakchich Café gives out a welcoming feeling with its colourful mosaic facade. Inside, bright yellow walls light up the room, as the singular style of decoration catches the eye. Wallpapers and lamps have all been sourced from recycled materials. The same goes for the multicoloured wooden tables, bench seats and ottomans. They all create an impression as strong as the gigantic French mailbox that stands in the back of the room. Here, traditional recipes are all prepared with fresh ingredients. Choose the veggie tajine or one of the Moroccan salads, with avocado or chicken added for a twist. During the afternoon, you can order a Moroccan-style ristretto, served with some beghrirs, delicious pancakes drenched in honey. Let yourself go and the solar atmosphere of Bakchich Café will carry you away from the urban bustle.

Bakchich Café
Rue Riad Zitoun el Jdid
Marrakesh 40000

+212 (0) 661 48 86 92

www.facebook.com/BakchichCafe/ ﻿

Menu: from 80 MAD

content.title: Luxurious authenticity at the Riad de Tarabel

introduction.small: The combination of Second Empire furniture and refined decoration gives a sumptuous pomp to the Riad de Tarabel, right in the heart of Marrakech's medina.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Luxurious authenticity at the Riad de Tarabel

paragraphs.text:
Next to the Sidi Abdelaziz street, the Riad de Tarabel showcases a French colonial style with a rich historical background. It is based on large central patio lined with orange groves and covered with a lush lawn. At the back of the garden, you will find a huge grey-and-black-tiled outdoor swimming pool and wicker deckchairs. Close by, a charming orangey bar offers a large selection of freshly squeezed juices, hot drinks and traditional pastries for a snacking break. Back at the riad, the ten rooms and suites reveal a poetic ambiance with charcoal grey shutters, black lacquered furniture, shiny chandeliers and Venetian mirrors. Particular attention has been paid to every detail: closets are lined with leather, lights are subdued and the white sheets have been cut from the finest cloth. At sunset, gaze at the roofs of Marrakech from the terrace overlooking the Medina. An ideal landing spot for your stay on Moroccan soil.

Riad de Tarabel
Derb Sraghna
Marrakech 40000

+212 661 989 782

www.riad-de-tarabel.com/en/welcome/﻿

Rooms: from 2,067 MAD

content.title: Baromètre Marrakech, revisited gastronomy in a speakeasy atmosphere

introduction.small: At Baromètre, you come for a drink and stay for dinner. A unique experience amid the “Red City”.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Baromètre Marrakech, revisited gastronomy in a speakeasy atmosphere

paragraphs.text:
This new address has fast become one of the major spots of the Gueliz neighbourhood, in the heart of the Medina. You will not find any signage, just a capital B visible from the street. It thus signals the first Moroccan bar devoted to mixology, the art of making cocktails.
The intimate decoration and industrial touches are enhanced by the use of various glass jars and weird mixtures (homemade macerations, mixes of herbs…) exposed here and there. They blend perfectly with an iron counter and lighting fixtures worthy of a modern art museum. Such is the universe of this trendy bar that also hides a gastronomical restaurant. For a second space allows patrons to delve in a Mediterranean-influenced menu that changes with every season. Roasted John Dory fish with olives, served with verbena rice, or savoury tomato-basil macaroons are some of the gems you should expect.
In this high temple of the night – where it is recommended to drink in moderation – the promise of an ambiance like no other, as well as incredible recipes, stimulate customers to come back as quickly as possible.

Baromètre Marrakech
Rue Moulay Ali
40000 Marrakech

+212 (0) 524 37 90 12

Cocktails: from 80 MAD

www.facebook.com/barometremarrakech/

content.title: Promenade around the Koutoubia mosque

introduction.small: The Koutoubia minaret is a proof of Marrakech's architectural richness. Visual point of reference for anyone who wants to discover the city, you can gaze at it from the surrounding gardens.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Promenade around the Koutoubia mosque

paragraphs.text:
Walking around Marrakech, climb up the fortifications, past enormous gates and beautiful gardens. Spend some time on Jemaa el-Fna square, where storytellers and tooth pullers rub shoulders with dancers and snake charmers when night falls. A few metres away from the square stands the Koutoubia minaret, another of the city's major symbols. Built under the Almoravid dynasty in the 12th century, this magnificent sacred structure is open to public and remains very popular.
You can catch a glimpse of the 69-metre high minaret up to 30 kilometres away. From up close, it reveals an impressive decorative process, from paintings to earthenware (this Moorish influence can be traced as far as Seville and its Giralda, a replica of the Koutoubia minaret). Right behind the mosque, end your stroll while enjoying the quiet peace of Lalla Hasna gardens. From orange trees to rose gardens, locals love to gather there when the day cools off. This stroll is a very good opportunity to discover Marrakech's medina, designated a UNESCO world heritage site.

content.title: Majorelle Blue

introduction.small: Intense, bright and sheltered from the tumult of the city, the Majorelle Garden are an invitation to lose yourself as you would in a work of art. A live painting that has become a symbol of Marrakech.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Majorelle Blue

paragraphs.text:
While living in the medina of Marrakech, painter Jacques Majorelle fell in love with a superb property, at the edge of the Palmeraie. He bought it in 1923 and underwent huge construction work, notably building a Le Corbusier-inspired artist studio. Most importantly, he created a garden at once lush, exotic, full of life, slowly put together by bringing plants from five continents in the course of his journeys: cacti, bougainvilleas, bamboos, banana and palm trees.
Along the way, the garden evolved and fountains and ponds were brought in to decorate the property. As a finishing touch, the painter created the unique Majorelle Blue, an ultramarine, cobalt blue that he used to paint the walls of his studio, and later used all around the garden. This blue made him famous around the world.
Today, the property has become a museum. It is one of the most visited spots in Marrakech, a poetic cathedral of shapes and colours where time stands still.

Majorelle Garden
Rue Yves Saint Laurent
40090 Marrakech

+212 524 31 30 47

http://jardinmajorelle.com

content.title: Marrakech, a new bright star in the golfing world

introduction.small: 12 golf courses have turned Marrakech and its surroundings into Northern Africa's little Florida.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Marrakech, a new bright star in the golfing world

paragraphs.text:
If not for the breathtaking view onto the foothills of the High Atlas and mild temperatures even in the dead of winter, you'd think you're stepping on a Florida green fee. And yet, yes, you are in Marrakech, the newest trendy destination of golf lovers, a city that sees golf courses and clubs crop up all over the place. There is an embarrassment of riches, whether in or out of the Red City. You may choose an entire round or simply 9 holes, this or that course conceived by a famed designer, all according to your mood of the moment...
For those who wish to use their golf clubs on one of the most beautiful greens in the world, the Old Course of the Marrakech Royal Golf Club proves to be a necessary stop, offering a 3.7-mile long par 72. Setting foot in the steps of Ike Eisenhower or Winston Churchill while breathing a particularly scented air (15,000 trees including palm trees, orange trees, eucalyptuses, Alep pine trees and olive groves) is a personal trophy worth going after. Facing the Royal Golf, do not miss the Amelkis golf club, beautiful and prestigious 27-hole course.

Marrakech Royal Golf
Ancienne route de Ouarzazate
BP 634
40000 Marrakech

+212 524 40 98 28

www.royalgolfmarrakech.com

Amelkis Golf
Km 12 ancienne route de Ouarzazate
40000 Marrakech

+212 524 40 44 14

www.golfamelkis.com

content.title: Picnic at Lalla Takerkoust lake

introduction.small: Get away for a day to this sumptuous oasis, where time seems to stop.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Picnic at Lalla Takerkoust lake

paragraphs.text:
Only a few miles away and accessible from Marrakech via the Amizmiz road, Lalla Takerkoust lake owes its name to the local patron saint. At the foot of the Atlas mountain, this artificial stretch of water appeared a century ago due the construction of a dam. Inhabitants of Marrakech love to go there and enjoy a cool day, away from the ebullient Red City.
Enjoy moments of peace and quiet and take a dip in the lake. The place also offers a unique landscape for a convivial picnic. For those who love to bask in the sun, the lakeshores are very welcoming. Sports enthusiasts will be able to practice paddle boat, windsurfing and canoeing. If you want to explore the surroundings, quads and motorcycles are available. And finally, if you want to prolong your stay, it is possible to sleep on the spot, in either inns or guesthouses.

Lalla Takerkoust lake
Al Haouz province
Km 30 route d'Amizmiz
40000 Marrakech

content.title: Argan oil, treasure of Marrakech

introduction.small: A traditional and fine product that is sought after for gustatory and cosmetic properties as well as medicinal use.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Argan oil, treasure of Marrakech

paragraphs.text:
Yesterday, Moroccan sultans made it a gift to European leaders. Trade has since developed in Marrakech around this exceptional elixir, the fabrication of which rests exclusively upon the shoulders of craftswomen working daily in cooperatives. This plant oil is extracted from a hard-shelled nut, covered by the pulp of the fruit growing on argan trees.
When used for cooking, argan oil will add a subtle hazelnut flavour to your dish, but it is first and foremost used as a form of disease prevention. Additionally, argan oil is widely used in cosmetics, making the most of its moisturizing, nourishing and healing properties. Besides, it has the merit of being 100% organic. You can find some in the many souks of the city, yet we recommend visiting one of the nearby cooperatives to buy your oil at the root and therefore discover the various stages of the production process. On the road to Essaouira, make a stop at the Tiguemine Argan cooperative or visit the Marjana one.

content.title: Ski in Oukaïmeden

introduction.small: It is considered one of the best ski resorts in Morocco. Only a stone's throw away from the Sahara dunes, the highest African resort will make you crave for some more thrills.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Ski in Oukaïmeden

paragraphs.text:
Surprising as it may appear to some, ski addicts have every occasion to enjoy themselves near Marrakech. The 9,000-feet high Oukaïmeden ski resort offers ski-tows and chairlifts to take you up twelve miles of sun-drenched slopes. Do not miss the red rocks bearing cave paintings from the Bronze Age at the entrance of the resort. Oukaïmeden is a hotspot of the Moroccan jet-set, but the village of the same name stills conveys a genuine and exotic feeling, a few miles away from Marrakech.
Travellers who wish to ski on vast and untouched areas will find exactly what they're looking for. For a moment of relaxation, make an opportune stop at Chez Juju, a charming inn nestled up the slopes. Finally, various activities are available to please the most curious: mule rides, paragliding, hang-gliding, rock climbing, carp fishing and trekking on the Toubkal Mount are only some of them. And you're sure to love the view onto the Ouarzazate plain!

Oukaimeden
Douar
Al Haouz Province
42152 Marrakech

+212 610 64 48 75

http://toubkal-ski.tw.ma/

content.title: The nicest souks of the Kingdom

introduction.small: Visit the fabulous souks of Marrakech, in the caravan trails of old.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The nicest souks of the Kingdom

paragraphs.text:
To understand the nature of the souks in Marrakech, you have to lose yourself in the twists and turns of the city's history and go back in time, from its creation until now. This dizzying immersion in the Kingdom's past will take you to an era when caravan drivers came here to exchange food products and commodities before facing the Moroccan desert.
In Marrakech, the hustle and bustle of the souks is the result of some 40,000 craftsmen. In all, 18 souks have been inventoried and divided into bodies of trade (music instruments repairmen, metalworkers, woodworkers, leather craftsmen, basket makers, spices dealers and other dyers). From oriental slippers to spices, jewellery, rugs and leather bags, this is a real labyrinth where you can meander your way around scents, colours and sounds. From the famous Jemaa el-Fna square (designated a UNESCO Intangible cultural heritage in 2001), you will bask in the soft frenzy of more than 20 hectares of narrow streets, oblivious to the surrounding importation stores.

Jemaa el-Fna square
Derb Chtouka
40008 Marrakech

content.title: Spoiled at Bain Bleu

introduction.small: Traditional hammam is a must-do in Marrakech. To relax after a long day walking the city streets, head over to the Bain Bleu.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Spoiled at Bain Bleu

paragraphs.text:
Just a short walk away from Jemaa el-Fna square, Le Bain Bleu keeps Eastern traditions and savoir-faire alive in the field of body care. It has to be known that hammam bathing is an ancestral ritual in Morocco.
First, you have to adapt to the heat and stay in a tempered room for a few minutes. Then move on to the next, warmer, room, to open up the pores of your skin, detoxify the body and activate blood circulation. Time has come for some exfoliation using black soap of course, to remove dead cells. For the ritual to be complete, make yourself comfortable in a massage room offering subdued lighting as well as rose, marjoram and eucalyptus scents. Be sure that the massage will be performed by skilful hands. Le Bain Bleu also offers a swimming pool, a Jacuzzi and a resting room... where traditional mint tea always awaits you.

Le Bain Bleu
32 Derb Chorfa Lakbir
Mouassine
40008 Marrakech

+212 524 38 38 04

http://www.lebainbleu.com

content.title: Getting around in Marrakech

introduction.small: Explore every inch of the city in any way possible.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Getting around in Marrakech

paragraphs.text:
Start by walking around the city, visiting the huge souks of the Jemaa el-Fna place, and then lose yourself in the charming and narrow streets of the medina. To save some leg power, you'd rather count on skilful cab drivers to move around, as driving in Marrakech is akin to stock-car competing and not relaxing in the least bit. For short trips, use ‘small taxi cabs”, and if you wish to move outside of town, use bigger ones, offering more engine power.
Riding a horse-drawn carriage is always enchanting. Head to Jemaa el-Fna square where you are sure to find one according to your price range. More unusual is the camel ride, which is possible just outside of Marrakech. To look upon both the city and the faraway mountains of the Atlas range, opt for the hot-air balloon ride.

content.title: Mint tea in Marrakech

introduction.small: Whether in a grand hotel or above a souk market, drinking some mint tea will always be an unforgettable experience.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Mint tea in Marrakech

paragraphs.text:
Very popular tradition in Japan, tea ceremonies are just as genuine and ceremonial in Marrakech. Prepared with freshly infused leaves, mint tea may be sweet, peppered and hot but never scalding. It may seem simple and yet, you will notice it doesn't hold the same flavours when it is made by the book, in an Eastern setting while admiring a sunset over the Atlas mountains with a few notes of oud and kwitra, specific Arabo-Andalusian instruments, filling the air.
Take advantage of that mint tea experience to discover the nicest hotels in town, for instance Le Mandarin Oriental, the Four Seasons and the Royal Mansour. Or go to La Mamounia luxury hotel and wander around the garden filled with hundred-year old olive trees to reach Le Menzeh pavilion, where a waiter will offer you delicious traditional pastries along the tea. After some polite bargaining in the souk, leave the turmoil of lively narrow streets and rise above at the Terrasse des Épices. While walking up the staircase, you'll enjoy a magnificent view onto the roofs of the souk. An ‘open-air' mint tea experience.

Le Menzeh
La Mamounia Marrakech Hotel
Avenue Bab Jdid
40040 Marrakech

+212 524 38 86 00

www.mamounia.com

La Terrasse des Épices
15 souk Cherifia
Sidi Abdelaziz
40040 Marrakech

+212 524 37 59 04

https://terrassedesepices.com

Mandarin Oriental
Route du Golf Royal
40000 Marrakech

+212 524 29 88 88

www.mandarinoriental.com/marrakesh/

Four Seasons Resort Marrakech
1 boulevard de la Menara
40000 Marrakech

+212 524 35 92 00

https://terrassedesepices.com

Royal Mansour
Rue Abou Abbas el Sebti
40000 Marrakech

+212 529 80 80 80

www.royalmansour.com

content.title: The madrasa, marvel of Arab and Andalusian architecture

introduction.small: The word madrasa refers to a Koranic school. Built in the 16th century, the madrasa of Marrakech is the most sumptuous of its time. It is absolutely worth a visit.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The madrasa, marvel of Arab and Andalusian architecture

paragraphs.text:
You have to imagine the Ben Youssef madrasa in its prime. A name that travelled the world well beyond the frontiers of the Kingdom, with almost a thousand knowledge-hungry students being taught in its midst. However, lessons were taking place in the Ben Youssef mosque nearby, not in the main building, which was used as a sort of campus. Nowadays, it is possible to visit the rooms, notably those on the first floor, the windows of which give onto the madrasa's little courtyards. They are testimonies of the student life of the era. With a maximum size of 9 square metres for up to four classmates, their bareness is in stark contrast with the richness and refinement of the patio and the prayer rooms. Closed in 1960, the building was completely renovated to restore its former splendour and allow visitors to discover the site in the best possible manner.

Ben Youssef Madrasa
Place Ben Youssef
40000 Marrakech

+212 524 44 18 93

www.medersa-ben-youssef.com

content.title: Dar Si Saïd, the palace that became a museum

introduction.small: Former home of a War Minister built in the second half of the 19th century, the place has been turned into a regional arts and crafts museum in 1932.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Dar Si Saïd, the palace that became a museum

paragraphs.text:
Within the museum, you will find a lovely patio revealing a carved wood gazebo in its midst, surrounded by flowers trees, flowers and a mosaic fountain. This idyllic setting adds a touch of natural beauty to the visit. When you leave the sumptuous garden and enter the first rooms of the museum building, you will discover the history and beauty of Morocco through the filter of decorative and religious arts.
Most of the items in the collections originate from and the southern part of the country. They are testimonies of regional craftsmanship in the 19th and 20th centuries. The museum exhibits woodwork symbols of Islamic craft, jewellery, pottery, ceramics, weapons, fabrics and various archaeological items. In addition to the objects on display, you will be amazed by the room decoration. Between the chandeliers, engravings and mosaics, you will not know which way to turn in this palace worthy of enchanting Middle-Eastern tales! And you will therefore understand why Dar Si Said is one of the key monuments in .

Dar Si Saïd (Moroccan arts museum)
Derb El Bahia‬‬‬‬‬‬‬
Riad Zitoun el-Jedid‬
40000

+212 524 38 95 64

content.title: Saadian tombs, Spanish-Moorish gems

introduction.small: The Saadian era was a golden age for Marrakech. These mausoleums are the sole remnants of the various splendours of this dynasty.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Saadian tombs, Spanish-Moorish gems

paragraphs.text:
North of the Almohad Kasbah, the Saadian tombs were being built in the late 16th century by Saadian sultan Ahmad al-Mansur to shelter the graves of his forebears. In the 18th century, sultan Moulay Ismail ibn Sharif rose to power and decided to erase all signs of the former dynasty. As a consequence, a wall was built around the graves. The royal mausoleum has been rediscovered in 1917 by the Fine Arts service, entrusted with the restoration of this architectural gem, typical of the 16th and 17th centuries Spanish-Moorish styles.
Do not miss to visit the room of the twelve columns. It houses the tomb of Saadian sultan Ahmed El Mansour. Ceilings, made in cedar wood and stucco, are finely crafted, and the graves are built in Carrara marble. Have a careful look at the tombs, as some carry poetic epitaphs.

Saadian tombs
Rue de la Kasbah
40000 Marrakech

+212 654 57 22 05

www.tombeaux-saadiens.com

content.title: Embrace the desert

introduction.small: Set out for the quiet Agafay desert and its incredible dunes, Kasbahs and Berber villages over 18 miles.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Embrace the desert

paragraphs.text:
Utter the word ‘desert' and the Sahara will surely come to mind first. The Agafay desert however, though less known and less frequented, is much closer to Marrakech (the Sahara is about 62 miles away) and is sure to win you over with its uniqueness. White dunes of rocks make up most of this mineral desert, a natural gem surprising visitors with its shiny beauty.
You will also find an oasis set in a valley, the green colour of which offers a stark contrast with the surrounding rocky landscapes. You may elect to roam the place by quad, buggy or 4x4. To sleep on the spot, you may either set up camp or book a night in a nearby bivouac. There's always the option to sleep in old farm turned guesthouse. Whether for one or several days, this getaway is for sure an unusual experience... and will remain one of your fondest memories.

content.title: La Paillote, the best French cuisine in Marrakech

introduction.small: Enjoy a unique moment surrounded by hundred-year-old olive trees.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Paillote, the best French cuisine in Marrakech

paragraphs.text:
A few miles from the centre of Marrakech, La Paillote is peaceful and welcoming. In this charming and elegantly decorated colonial restaurant, you may have dinner in a cosy interior space or luscious outdoor setting. Discover a simple and mastered menu. Produce is put forward thanks to the talent of the staff and quality of the local ingredients.
For starters, the chef will have you taste his sardine filets, just warm with mashed carrot and gouda and parmesan shortbread. Duck magret will follow, served with apples with ginger and roasted peaches. If you prefer fish, you'll enjoy monkfish medallions in parsley tomato sauce and argan oil mist. Dessert will be just as savoury: milk and caramelized almond pastilla and seasonal fruits.

La Paillote
Km 4 route d'Amizmiz
Marrakech

+212 663 87 96 05

www.lapaillote.ma

Menu: around 230 MAD

content.title: La Trattoria Di Giancarlo, la Dolce Vita

introduction.small: The perfect dreamy setting for farniente with friends or a romantic savoury Italian dinner.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Trattoria Di Giancarlo, la Dolce Vita

paragraphs.text:
Yves Saint Laurent, Armani, or Catherine Deneuve were regulars and turned this Marrakech restaurant into a landmark. In a 1920s décor subtly mixing Venetian and Moroccan art, travellers can enjoy a drink before dinner in the Art deco lounge, as beautiful as it is comfortable. With subdued lighting as well as discreet and elegant crowd, the Trattoria Di Giancarlo is a good place for a pleasant break.
As soon as you finish your drink, it's time to go to your table. You can dine inside or outside, but we recommend the famous luscious green patio in the back. Around a blue green pond lit with thousands of lanterns, pretty wrought iron tables are set under a huge glass canopy through which you can look up at the stars at night. The menu offers the best Italian specialities. For starters, burrata lovers will be in heaven. Don't miss the duck magret with grapes and red apple!

Trattoria Di Giancarlo
179 rue Mohamed Beqal
Guéliz
40000 Marrakech

+212 524 432 641

Menu: around 300 MAD

content.title: Moroccan pastries: very sugary temptations

introduction.small: Time has come to be… gluttonous! Follow us in our crazy Moroccan treats marathon. We found their headquarters.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Moroccan pastries: very sugary temptations

paragraphs.text:
Tradition asks that mint tea be served three times: The first glass is as gentle as life, The second is as strong as love, The third is as bitter as death. In order to get passed the bitterness, it is recommended to have a Moroccan pastry with the third glass – or, let's go crazy with the first and second. Usually made of almonds, orange blossom and honey and therefore very sugary, they will make you crave for some more...
Since 1985, Hakima Alami owns what is generally considered the best bakery in Marrakech. Al Jawda, in the Guéliz district, is brimming with exquisite makroudhs, crispy kaab el Ghazal (gazelle horns), bewitching chocolate creations and honey cigar rolls. The unconventional entrance is enticing and surprising, luring you with orange and sugar scents that will kindle your appetite. No-holds-barred food spree!

Al Jawda bakery – Chez Mme Alami
11 rue de la Liberté
Guéliz
40000 Marrakech

+212 524 43 38 97

www.al-jawda.com

content.title: Like a rolling quad

introduction.small: Keep horses and camels for touristy trips and enjoy quad biking instead, accompanied by professionals taking you across wild tracks.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Like a rolling quad

paragraphs.text:
Are you looking for thrills? Take a half-day (or more) to discover Marrakech and its surroundings in a different manner. Riding this four-wheeled bike gives you a taste of freedom and allows you to appreciate superb landscapes that will pass before your eyes at just the right speed. Fear not, this experience is not meant for accomplished riders only. All newcomers are welcome to try if they are careful as quads are easy to drive.
Whether in the Palmeraie up to the Lalla Takerkoust lake 21 miles away, or even further away around the Kik plateau, this getaway is a perfect opportunity to escape the hustle and bustle of the big city, in exchange for big spaces and gorgeous roads leading up the Atlas mountains. If you forgot your driving licence, note that it is not mandatory. Head for new adventures into the wild!

content.title: Dar Yacout, royal treat

introduction.small: It is the nighttime meeting spot of genuine food lovers. Right in the heart of the medina, come discover this magnificent and exquisite Moroccan classic.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Dar Yacout, royal treat

paragraphs.text:
Whether you prefer the hushed atmosphere on the ground floor or the breathtaking view on the top floor, the cuisine will impress you. Start by strolling around the restaurant, beneath authentic carved ceilings brought to life by traditional music, or stroll around the pond lined with lanterns.
Once seated at King Hassan II's table, enjoy the chef's menu, as generous as it is delicious. In this magical setting, enjoy the many Moroccan salads, breath in the flavours of the olive chicken beldi and brace yourself for a couscous with its semolina and vegetables. For dessert, order cinnamon topped orange slices.
Spend time on the paved terrace of this exceptional riad before taking your leave. The stunning panoramic view of the medina and Koutoubia complement this majestic place.

Dar Yacout
79 Derb Sidi Ahmed Soussi
Bab Doukkala
40000 Marrakech

+212 524 38 29 29

www.yacout.ma/

Menu: around 700 MAD

content.title: Al Fassia, let Moroccan gastronomy whisk you away

introduction.small: The city's gustatory benchmark, Al Fassia, will seduce traditional cuisine lovers.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Al Fassia, let Moroccan gastronomy whisk you away

paragraphs.text:
Dive into oriental cuisine, here in the heart of the Gueliz neighbourhood. This Moroccan establishment with a casual feel is probably one of the best restaurants in town. This warm and cosy restaurant invites you to discover its thousand-and-one-flavour dishes.
Refined and delicious, this all-women cuisine is full of surprises. Choose the vegetable and meat briouats or a succulent chicken pastilla to begin with, continue on to a delightful olive and crystallised lemon tagine, the restaurant's speciality. For dessert, enjoy a fresh orange and cinnamon fruit salad and if you're still hungry, pick at a few cornes de gazelle served with mint tea.

Al Fassia
55 boulevard Mohamed Zerktouni
40000 Marrakech

+212 524 43 40 60

www.alfassia.com/our-restaurant/

Menu: about 230 MAD

content.title: Le Bô & Zin, see and be seen

introduction.small: The place to be for a fancy dinner that will turn into a party.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Bô & Zin, see and be seen

paragraphs.text:
The booking has been made, your friends are invited: tonight you're going to Bô & Zin, an essential stop in Marrakech's nightlife. Some will prefer dining outside near the ponds in the exotic garden, others on the dimly lit veranda. Either way, you won't stay in your seat long, as the vibe will encourage you to get up, dance, have a drink and chat with the other patrons. There's no saying what time you will be headed home since there is always something to keep you here. A safe bet for the past 12 years, Bô & Zin is always in style. The menu takes you around the world: Morocco, Thailand or France (chicken stir fry with cashews, spit roasted lamb confit, mi-cuit salmon). These typical fusion cuisine items are a good introduction to a fun night.

Bô & Zin
Km 3,5 route de l'Ourika
40000 Marrakech

+212 524 38 80 12

www.bo-zin.com

Menu: around 500 MAD

content.title: La Villa des Orangers, refinement at its finest

introduction.small: You will enjoy this gem of an address, an intimate restaurant that offers the perfect setting for those who enjoy cosy surroundings and romantic dinners.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Villa des Orangers, refinement at its finest

paragraphs.text:
Here, the atmosphere stands in stark contrast with the busy nearby streets. As soon as you enter the porch, all goes quiet. Your eyes are drawn to the elegant design of this charming address. This riad dates back to the 1930s and was owned by a Marrakech notable until 1998. Behind the mashrabiya stands a small luxury hotel, a rectangular pool surrounded by olive and orange trees where you can enjoy a delightful dinner. The delicate trickling from the interior courtyard fountain will escort you as you walk to the dining room – a cosy room with woodpanelling.
La Villa des Orangers is an exceptional restaurant, open to outside guests at night. Come and discover the local terroir and delicate Mediterranean cuisine. The chef constantly renews his creations an offers colourful dishes, combining spices and herbs, inspired by tradition with a modern twist. Crayfish papillotes with carrots and orange olive oil emulsion, Atlas snail dumplings, vegetable briouats, garlic and harissa shrimp with caramelised lemon will create marvellous memories. And don't forget to admire the magnificent view on the Koutoubia minaret from the rooftop.

La Villa des Orangers
6 rue Sidi Mimoun
40000 Marrakech

+212 524 38 46 38

www.villadesorangers.com

Menu: around 580 MAD

content.title: Ling Ling enchanting your senses

introduction.small: Inaugurated in August 2016, Ling Ling will enchant your senses. The Asian bar-restaurant is located in the heart of the lavish Mandarin Oriental of the ochre city.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Ling Ling enchanting your senses

paragraphs.text:
On August 22nd, 2016, the Mandarin Oriental announced its collaboration with the Hakkasan group during the unveiling of a novel concept in Marrakech. Inspired by Japanese izakayas, Ling Ling offers vibrant Asian cuisine and creative signature cocktails, conceived by a team of award winning mixologists. This new incarnation of elegant and chic Marrakech, owes its excellent traditional dishes to the maestria of international chef Ho Chee Boon. For dinner: grilled Shanghai dumplings, roast duck with black truffle and steamed chocolate balls. Or you may prefer the subtle flavours of the smoked green jasmine tea prime rib.
At the end of this savoury meal, let the breathtaking view of the snow-capped Atlas mountains whisk you away or enjoy the quiet ponds and gardens of the Mandarin Oriental.

Mandarin Oriental Marrakech
Route du Golf Royal
40000 Marrakech

+212 524 29 88 88

lingling.hakkasan.com/

Menu: from 550 MAD

content.title: Shopping in Marrakech: quality over quantity!

introduction.small: Among ruins of the Berber Empire, palaces built around the Battle of Alcazar and Saadian tombs, here are some excellent spots to simply go shopping.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Shopping in Marrakech: quality over quantity!

paragraphs.text:
Looking halfway between an industrial loft and a traditional Moroccan house, Valérie Barkowski's shop is selling impeccable household linen. Benjaz Broderie will fulfil your need to own red and ochre arabesque-patterns. If you want to redecorate your home, we recommend exploring the universe of Corinne Bensimon, combining traditional craft and contemporary inspirations, and Mustapha Blaoui, creating unique rugs and doors. At Lup31 Design, simple and old fashioned components of Moroccan daily life have been turned into real gems by the owner. In the medina and the industrial area of the city as well, Chabi Chic sheds a light on traditional tableware and furniture, when the Owl boutique opens its doors onto a bobo-chic haven of sorts.
If you feel ready to wear the country's colours, head over to Topolina for some real vintage items, Kaftan Queen for its bohemian spirit, Fadila El Gadi for the respect of Moroccan traditions and Fahmi for leather skins. Last but not least, the Atika Marrakech footwear temple awaits you in the Guéliz district.

V. Barkowski Store

+212 524 37 50 13

http://valeriebarkowski.com

+212 524 33 51 30

http://www.benjaz.ma

content.title: Bazaar Café, with a Mediterranean touch

introduction.small: Just a few steps from the Jemaa el-Fna square, the Bazaar Café offers dishes and tapas inspired by Moroccan and Mediterranean cuisine.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Bazaar Café, with a Mediterranean touch

paragraphs.text:
After visiting the souk, stop by the Bazaar Café for a delicious break. Enjoy the panoramic terrace, overlooking the roofs of Marrakech and in the distance, the snow-capped Atlas mountains. The restaurant brings you a selection of Moroccan and Mediterranean culinary treasures in an elegant, quiet and comfortable setting.
For lunch or dinner, order from the menu or perhaps indulge in the specials. Ahmed, your host, uses organic and local produce exclusively, with many vegan and vegetarian options. Pick some savoury tapas inspired by the flavours of Morocco, Lebanon, Spain, Italy or Greece for sharing. The grilled sardines are first-rate, and the almond ice cream is a genuine delight! Perfect to enjoy with a glass of mint tea.

Bazaar Café
24B, Derb Sidi El Yamani
40000 Marrakech

+212 524 38 72 83

www.bazaarcafe.ma

Menu: around 95 MAD

content.title: Enjoy the Moroccan Atlas and a few thrills along the way

introduction.small: Far from the busy streets of the medina, take off with family or friends and enjoy various outdoor activities.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Enjoy the Moroccan Atlas and a few thrills along the way

paragraphs.text:
Right off Marrakech, you will have every opportunity to practice playful and sports activities, and even seek thrills in an extraordinary natural habitat. From horse to mountain bike riding, treetop adventures and high rope crossings, the young and old alike will delight in outdoor exercise.
South of the city, Les Terres d'Amanar is the largest aerial ground of the African continent, an ideal location to use ziplines over huge red canyons. For an afternoon devoted to treetop adventures, choose Paloozaland, a vast theme park just outside of Marrakech. It offers circuits adapted for all levels. And if you have a real taste for extreme odysseys, get ready as a trek on the slopes of the Atlas mountains will take you to reach the summits and discover remote Berber villages. Several associations based in Marrakech will help you prepare for the expedition!

Les Terres d'Amanar
Douar Akli
Town of Tahannaout
El Haouz Province

+212 524 43 81 03

www.terresdamanar.com

Paloozaland
Koudiate laabid
Route de Casablanca

+212 524 05 95 04
www.paloozaland.com/attraction/Aventure

content.title: Monkfish corn couscous by Fatema Hal

introduction.small: The Es Saadi Palace has offered Fatema Hal the kitchen keys to its gastronomic restaurant. As an ambassador of Moroccan cuisine in Paris, she retells an unusual couscous story for us.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Monkfish corn couscous by Fatema Hal

paragraphs.text:
Based on the third and last floor of the Es Saadi Gardens & Resort palace, the Cour des Lions restaurant offers an unobstructed vista onto the Atlas mountains and the whole domain. The whole decoration is made of stone filigree and plaster cast in the Arab-Andalusian style. Before sitting at the table, guests are welcome to spend some time in the main salon displaying incredible sofas.
In the kitchen, chef Fatema Hal wants to bring ancestral dishes of Moroccan cuisine back into fashion. These include the genuine ras el-hanout mourouzia (a recipe that dates back to the 12th century), pigeon pastille and the imperial Madfoun, more commonly known as ‘veiled couscous'...

Fatema Hal's recipe: carve medallions of monkfish (3.3 pounds for 10 servings) and ask the fishmonger not to throw the heads away, as you will use them in the broth. Boil water in the lower pot of the couscous maker and put the corn couscous in the upper one. Seal the two pots and bring them to the boil. In a cooking pot, drop 4 spoons of olive oil, 3 minced onions, a monkfish head (for taste), 2 teaspoons of turmeric, 1 spoon of salt and 1 spoon of pepper, 3 squashed garlic cloves and a bunch of chiselled cilantro. Pour water and bring them to the boil over an open flame. Reduce it and add the monkfish. Let it stew for 10 minutes. Keep warm and reserve. When couscous is ready, pour it in a hollow dish. Moisten in juice, add the monkfish medallions on top and onions and other vegetables around them. Serve with a side of broth.

La Cour des Lions
Es Saadi Gardens & Resort Marrakech
Rue Ibrahim el-Mazini
Hivernage
40000 Marrakech

+212 614 05 63 89

www.essaadi.com/en/restaurants/the-palace-restaurants/cour-des-lions

content.title: Nomad, authenticity perched up high

introduction.small: Only a few steps away from the famous place des Épices, the Nomad restaurant brings you authentic cuisine and local produce.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Nomad, authenticity perched up high

paragraphs.text:
As you take in the vibrant colours and enchanting scents of Rahba Lakdima, make time to rise above. The Nomad restaurant overlooks the busy souks and welcomes you to its sun drenched terrace all year round. Whether you're looking for a feast, a drink, or light snack, come taste the delicate Moroccan delights and discover a wide array of subtle spices.
Since 2014, the restaurant has been inviting chefs from around the world to cook local produce and herbs from nearby markets. A rich exchange of ideas and inspiration that could start a culinary “new wave” in Moroccan cuisine. From lamb tagine, zucchini and feta fritters, to cumin and ginger calamari from Agadir, you'll enjoy a delicious meal in this perched hideaway.

Nomad
1 Derb Aarjan
Médina
40000 Marrakech

+212 524 38 16 09

nomadMarrakech.com

Menu: around 150 MAD

content.title: Le Jardin, a few steps away from the Marrakech Museum

introduction.small: After the success of the Café des Epices, Kamal Laftimi opened a second restaurant, Le Jardin, just as trendy as the café.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Jardin, a few steps away from the Marrakech Museum

paragraphs.text:
Le Jardin is located in the heart of the souks. This 16th century riad is welcoming with its Franco-Moroccan feel, and both décor and cuisine are lovely. You can stop by for coffee or enjoy lunch or dinner. French architect Anne Favier freshened up the place while keeping its traditional Marrakchi style. The lounges and terraces are decorated in green hues, echoing the green garden beautifully lit with lanterns. The decoration is simple, and streamlined, providing the perfect oasis for lounging.
Pick the house specialty, the famous Moroccan grilled beef and lamb! On the menu, you will even find vegetarian grilled dishes. Taste the chicken pastilla or tagine, as both are delicious. Before you leave, come check out the Norya Ayron, a nice clothing store on the ground floor. Upstairs, the pretty decks overlook the souks. In the summertime, you can come watch outdoor screenings of classic movies.

Le Jardin
32 route Sidi Abdelaziz
40000 Marrakech

+212 524 37 82 95

lejardinmarrakech.com

Menu: around 210 MAD

content.title: Fairmont Royal Palm Marrakech, heaven on earth for golfers

introduction.small: The Mauritian group Beachcomber has brought its art of hospitality to the Royal Palm, an exceptional golf course that's become paradise for golf lovers.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Fairmont Royal Palm Marrakech, heaven on earth for golfers

paragraphs.text:
As the ultimate golf destination, Marrakech offers a dozen golf courses. No time to waste if you like hitting balls. The 18 hole Royal Palm Golf & Country Club was designed by Cabell B. Robinson and sits on a hilly landscape offering various bodies of water, as part of a huge estate where palms and fruit trees abound.
At the heart of this 185 acre course of greens and fairways, the Royal Palm provides luxurious accommodation, sweet harmony of Moroccan savoir-faire and Mauritian service. All the suites face the Atlas Mountains and the villas with private pools turn your stay into an unparalleled relaxing experience. After a few technical shots in the ‘bunkers', relax with a ‘Supreme Rose Massage' at the Clarins Spa. Treatments subtly combine Moroccan and Mauritian essences to bring in the Mauritius Royal Palm spirit. A delight!

Fairmont Royal Palm Marrakech
Km 12 route d'Amizmiz
BP 2470
40000 Marrakech

+212 524 48 78 00

www.fairmont.fr/marrakech/

Rooms: from 1,600 MAD

content.title: Selman, Morocco's soul unveiled

introduction.small: This hotel run by a Moroccan family is a favourite amongst demanding travellers, as nearby palaces have nothing on the Selman.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Selman, Morocco's soul unveiled

paragraphs.text:
The art of entertaining has always been nurtured in Morocco. As such, the Selman Marrakech hotel run by the Bennani Smires family stands as a proud ambassador. 55 suites, 5 riads and three outdoor pools – one of which is 88 yards long.
Inside, you can enjoy the elegant décor designed by Jacques Garcia, both modern and imprinted with Moroccan heritage. In the common areas you will be taken by the horse sculptures and by the beauty of the horses galloping semi-freely in the green meadows of the estate. The stud farm is home to stunning full breads and brings real authenticity to the place. If you're not staying here, know that the Sunday brunch is open to outside guests. When contemporary elegance flirts with traditions.

Selman Marrakech
Km 5 route d'Amizmiz
40160 Marrakech

+212 524 45 96 00

www.selman-marrakech.com

Rooms: from 3,500 MAD

content.title: Riad El Fenn, contemporary arts Palace

introduction.small: The Riad El Fenn in the heart of the Medina is expecting you. Walk into this palace full of mystery.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Riad El Fenn, contemporary arts Palace

paragraphs.text:
In 2004, El Fenn Riad was transformed from an abandoned traditional palace into an elegant boutique hotel by art gallery owner, Vanessa Branson. Away from the agitation of the medina, come enjoy the flamboyant colours of this Moroccan architectural gem. Walk down the vermeil corridor and prepare for the most relaxing stay: sleek suites and rooms invite you to meditate, while the spa, pools, screening room and garden provide leisure and entertainment. Sheltered from the city's heart-beat, the El Fenn Riad will encourage you to lounge on the fluffy banquettes on the roof top, carried away by birds singing. A cross between a Moroccan palace and an art gallery, the hotel displays Francis Upritchard art pieces, Terence Donovan photos and light fixtures by Batoul S'Himi. Give into the delightful serenity… the Atlas mountains are watching over you.

Riad El Fenn
2 Derb Moulay Abdullah Ben Hezzian
Bab El Ksour
Medina
40000 Marrakech

+212 524 44 12 10

https://el-fenn.com/

Rooms: from 2,140 MAD

content.title: Riad Camilia, a family home

introduction.small: Tucked away in the heart of the medina, a few steps away from the souks and the Jemaa el-Fna square, Camille invites you into her riad.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Riad Camilia, a family home

paragraphs.text:
It was love at first sight for Camille, the owner, when she first discovered this traditional house. The renovation turned the riad into a quiet guest-house, a true haven of rest amid the medina. Everything here has been carefully chosen, each object lovingly picked with a story to tell. The warm welcome, gentle service and authentic setting will make you feel right at home.
There are six rooms, that's it. Comfortable and roomy, each with its own decoration and all in pure Moroccan style: tadelakt, Berber rugs and wrought iron. The outside patio is a pure delight, as you can enjoy tea in the shade beneath the orange tree. The riad also offers a table d'hôte and steambath so that you can enjoy even more of this tucked away sanctuary.

Riad Camilia
Derb El Ouali n°9
Kaat Benahid,
40000 Marrakech

+212 524 44 30 81

www.riadcamilia.com

Rooms: from 1,392 MAD

content.title: Les Deux Tours Hotel, a delightful oriental dream

introduction.small: At the heart of the Palmeraie, set your eyes on the Deux Tours, perfect for exploring the riches of Marrakech.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Les Deux Tours Hotel, a delightful oriental dream

paragraphs.text:
Between shadows and light, the Deux Tours Hotel unveils its Arabian Nights feel, made of vaulted arcades, patios, secret alcoves with colourful zelliges and pise walls. You can stay in one of the 37 rooms or suites providing modern amenities and pure tradition. If you are seeking optimal rest, choose a private residence with pool or Jacuzzi.
Between two outings, stop by the Spa: take advantage of the steam bath, massage and detox drinks as you dive into wellness. Outside, enjoy the infinity pool and the stunning grounds. Hungry? Pick one of two restaurants, the Pergola for casual dining, or the Salammbô for an intimate dinner, where you will enjoy dishes inspired by traditional local cuisine and French gastronomy, assembling vegetables and herbs from the garden. Free shuttle service is provided between the hotel and the centre of Marrakech.

Les Deux Tours Marrakech Palmeraie
Douar Abiad
BP 513
Circuit de la Palmeraie
40000 Marrakech

+212 524 32 95 25

www.les-deux-tours.com

Rooms: from 1,340 MAD

content.title: Dar Sabra, design in the Palmeraie

introduction.small: Dar Sabra happens to be the most modern hotel in the Palmeraie. Welcome to contemporary Marrakech!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Dar Sabra, design in the Palmeraie

paragraphs.text:
The futuristic looking Dar Sabra hotel stands out in Marrakech. Hidden away in the heart of a luscious 5 acre garden, complete with two ponds and a huge pool, this unusual address houses a few monumental art pieces by artists from around the world. The 23 rooms and suites are spacious, each with its unique decoration, inspired by Moroccan, African, or Indian travels. Art deco or contemporary rooms are also available.
The restaurant offers traditional Moroccan cuisine prepared with fresh local produce. Breakfast and lunch are served by the pool or under the ‘Berber' tent. You can relax in the steam bath, or use one of the 2 massage rooms, as well as a Jacuzzi and heated lap pool. The hotel also has a high tech gym and tennis court.

Dar Sabra Hotel
Circuit de la Palmeraie
Douar Abiad
40000 Marrakech

+212 524 32 91 72

www.darsabra-marrakech.net

Rooms: from 1,361 MAD

content.title: The Mandaline Gardens, Oriental sweetness

introduction.small: Just off a quiet alley in the medina, soak up the oriental serenity of the Mandaline gardens.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The Mandaline Gardens, Oriental sweetness

paragraphs.text:
Just a few steps from the colourful and busy Jemaa el-Fna square, you will find the quiet Mandaline Gardens. This riad is a true oasis of relaxation in the touristy neighbourhood surrounding the Ben Youssef madrasa, an Arab-Andalusian architectural gem.
With authentic rugs, velvets and drapes, as well as modern touches, the owners Nicole, Francis and Mathieu welcome you into one of their 8 rooms, all very affordable. Let your hosts guide you through the alcoves and arches of this superb traditional building and relax with a massage or steam bath. You can end your day by the pool or on the rooftop terrace. Soak in the pink rays of the Moroccan sun as you enjoy traditional cuisine or simply meditate under a pergola.

Les Jardins Mandaline
55 Derb El Ferrane
Riad Lâarouss
Medina
40000 Marrakech

+212 524 38 22 95

www.lesjardins-mandaline.com

Rooms: from 325 MAD

content.title: Le Grand Café de la Poste, French brasserie style

introduction.small: For a business lunch or simple latte, breakfast under the pergola, or to seek out traditional French cuisine.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Grand Café de la Poste, French brasserie style

paragraphs.text:
Shelter behind the huge venetian blinds of the Café de La Poste to avoid the Marrakech heat. Sit on a rattan chair and grab the menu from the Carrara marble table. The dishes will remind you of France: bistros, all day service and servers waltzing between tables with their trays. In the large room or under the canopy, you may choose one of the typical French dishes: free-range chicken, slow roasted leg of lamb, steak tartare, sole meunière from Oualidia. The organic vegetables (sugar snap peas, extra fine string beans, baby lettuce, and miniature carrots) come from a local farm on Ourika road, exclusively grown for chef Philippe Duranton. An excellent address for a simple meeting.

Le Grand Café de la Poste
At the corner of boulevard El Mansour Eddahbi and avenue Imam Malik
40000 Marrakech

+212 524 43 30 38

www.grandcafedelaposte.restaurant

Menu: about 360 MAD

content.title: Dar Rhizlane, sweet and discreet

introduction.small: Away from the city's tumult, the hidden Dar Rhizlane welcomes you to a quiet and traditional stay.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Dar Rhizlane, sweet and discreet

paragraphs.text:
Nestled in the Hivernage neighbourhood, this large mansion is barely visible from the street. Behind tall walls and luscious plants, stands a Moorish house, a cross between a riad and a guest palace. Through the rod iron gate, enter the flower filled courtyard, a zellige fountain in its centre adding a touch of magic at sunset.
Inside, the 20 rooms and suites are decorated in traditional Moroccan style: amber shades, subtle lighting and chic furniture, linens designed by local artisans. The hotel also houses a spa – two massage rooms and a steam bath - a gym, as well as a restaurant serving excellent Moroccan cuisine.

Dar Rhizlane
Avenue Jnane El Harti
Hivernage neighbourhood
40000 Marrakech

+212 524 42 13 03

www.dar-rhizlane.com

Rooms: from 1,530 MAD

content.title: Riad Amina, a peaceful oasis in the heart of the medina

introduction.small: To the North of the medina stands the Amina Riad, seducing travellers who have come to stroll around the old fortified town.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Riad Amina, a peaceful oasis in the heart of the medina

paragraphs.text:
Behind a plain black door awaits a peaceful oasis. Set your bags down and enjoy your stay in Marrakech. Built around a green patio and lively fountain, ten comfortable and elegant rooms are spread out over two floors. These rooms look like suites, offering sitting rooms and bathrooms on par with oriental palaces.
You will instantly be seduced by the warm welcome of the riad's staff, kind and discreet. The hotel offers generous cooking that you can enjoy in the patio or in one of the dining rooms. Try the Tanija Marrakchia, a Moroccan speciality, and a true delight! Extra treat: the Jacuzzi on the panoramic terrace overlooking the rooftops.

Riad Amina
Sidi ben Slimane
Derb Si Mouh n° 1
40000 Marrakech

+212 524 38 13 63

http://riadamina.com/

Rooms: from 600 MAD

content.title: Beldi Country Club, a rose is a rose is a rose…

introduction.small: Perfect for a family visit to the red city, the Beldi remains a unique estate that will seduce those who care for everlasting simplicity.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Beldi Country Club, a rose is a rose is a rose…

paragraphs.text:
If you had to describe the Beldi Country Club in one word, it would be: roses. At the heart of a 37 acre olive grove and surrounded by 12 000 rosebushes, the hotel's 27 suites invite you to enjoy the sweet life. The incredible smell from the gardens will inspire the most romantic travellers. In the distance, the snowcapped Atlas mountains contrast against the blue sky. The estate feels very much like a douar – a typical small Moroccan village. Stroll down the alleys lined with orange trees to reach the villas and riads, as each room has its own terrace or private garden.
You may have lunch at the restaurant or by one of the four pools – the heated pool is in the orange grove. This stunning estate is fifteen minutes away from Marrakech, and welcomes outside guests to parts of the hotel during the day, come for a nap on a chaise by the pool or for lunch. At last, you may enjoy their babysitting services for your little ones and that calls for some hard-earned relaxation!

Beldi Country Club
Km 6 route du Barrage Cherifia
40008 Marrakech

+212 524 38 39 50

www.beldicountryclub.com

Rooms: from 2,000 MAD

content.title: CLIMATE AND WEATHER IN Marrakech
content.introduction: Located in the centre of Morocco, Marrakech enjoys a semiarid climate: mild winters and mild summers especially. The ideal time to visit Marrakech is from May to October when the area is sunny and warm, and the ocean breezes make the heat bearable.

content.title: Currency and Exchange Rates
content.description: The currency used in Marrakech is the Moroccan Dirham (MAD).
content.validity: The above exchange rate is given for information because is variable.

airports.title: MARRAKECH-MENARA AIRPORT
airports.description:
The Marrakech-Menara International Airport is located approximately five kilometres (three miles) southwest of Marrakech's city centre.
  • The airport has 3 terminals:
    • Terminal 1 (Air France)
    • Terminal 2
    • Terminal 3

Travelling between Marrakech and the airport:
  • By car
    • The airport is accessible by car via the Guemassa Avenue. Allow approximately between 15 to 20 minutes to reach the city centre.
    • A parking with a 363 capacity is located near the terminal 1. Count MAD 5 for the first 4 hours, MAD 10 for up to 12 hours, and MAD 30 per day. For long-term parking, count MAD 20 per 24 day.
    • Several car rental companies are located in the arrivals area of Terminal 1, 2 and 3.
  • By bus
    • The Bus line #19 runs from the airport every 20 to 30 minutes, and serves the major areas of the city (Jemaa el-Fna, Hivernage, Bab Doukkala, Guéliz, Marrakech railway station). The fare is MAD 30.
  • By taxi
    • Taxi ranks are located at the exit of terminal 1. Taxis are available 24/7.The trip takes about 15 minutes and costs MAD 70.
  • Services: shops, bars, restaurants, free Internet access (Wi-Fi), currency exchange, banks, ATMs, and a post office are all to be found in the airport.
  • Website: www.aeroport-de-marrakech-menara.com
  • Telephone: +212 (0) 524 44 79 10

transportation.title: GETTING AROUND Marrakech
transportation.description: Traffic in Marrakech is often chaotic. The ideal way to explore the city's tourist attractions is on foot, especially inside the medina, where vehicles are almost forbidden.

touristInformation.title: Visitor information
touristInformation.description: Upon your arrival in Marrakech, you can get in touch with local tourism professionals for further information and to help organise your stay.

information.title: Tourist Office of Marrakech
information.description:
Offers practical information and useful recommendations (accommodation, restaurants, public transport, festivals, cultural events, etc.).

  • Address: Bd Mohammed V, place Abdelmoumen Ben Ali, Marrakech
  • Telephone: +212 (0) 524 43 61 31
  • Website: https://en.infostourismemaroc.com/

information.title: Regional Tourism Board (CRT)
information.description:
Offers practical information and useful recommendations (accommodation, restaurants, public transport, festivals, cultural events, etc.).

  • Address: 42 rue Cadi Ayad, appartement 4, Guéliz, Marrakech
  • Telephone: +212 (0) 524 43 34 07

medical.title: Medical information
medical.description:
In order to travel in the best conditions and for your health and safety, we invite you to check all information regarding preventive measures and best practices to be respected, available on the official website of the French Ministry of Foreign Affairs: https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/en/country-files/

Your comfort, well-being and health are at the heart of Air France's concerns, and we want to help you prepare for your trip in the best way possible. Find out more about the measures taken to ensure safe travelling on our website: https://www.airfrance.fr/FR/en/common/page_flottante/information/coronavirus.htm#notre-engagement-sanitaire

See your doctor before you travel. It is also recommended to take out insurance covering medical expenses and repatriation before your trip. Marrakech counts several hospitals and medical institutions, as well as quality medical practitioners and health specialists.

information.title: Vaccinations
information.description:
No vaccine is mandatory to stay in Marrakech. However, it is recommended you protect yourself against hepatitis A and B, and typhoid.
For more information, contact your Air France International Vaccination Centre:

  • Address: 38, quai de Jemmapes, 75010 Paris
  • Website: www.vaccinations-airfrance.fr
  • Telephone: +33 (0)1 43 17 22 00
  • To make a vaccination appointment:
    • online (click here)
    • Call the centre at +33 (0)1 43 17 22 00

information.title: Food safety
information.description:
There are few risks regarding food safety in Morocco. However, it is recommended to:

  • carefully wash produce before eating
  • avoid eating raw food

information.title: Water
information.description: Tap water is safe to drink in Marrakech.

essentialPhrases.title: Essential phrases
essentialPhrases.introduction: Here are a few useful phrases in Moroccan Arabic that may be useful for your stay in Marrakech:
phrases: Hello / Good morning / Good afternoon: Sabah al-khair
What time is it ?: Kam el sa'ah?

localCalendar.title: FESTIVALS, HOLIDAYS AND OTHER ANNUAL EVENTS IN Marrakech
localCalendar.description: Every year, numerous holidays are celebrated in Marrakech. Below are the main dates for these festivities:

events.title: January 1: New Year's Day (national)
events.description: For the New Year, Marrakech offers many lively evening entertainments. Local gastronomy, spices, and music and dance colour the splendour of the Oriental night, which is celebrated in restaurants and nightclubs throughout the Moroccan city, making for an unforgettable New Year's Eve.

events.title: January 11: Manifesto of Independence (national)
events.description: Morocco celebrates the signing of the Manifesto, which symbolises the end of colonisation and the birth of independence.

events.title: Third month of the Islamic calendar (date changes each year): Eid Al Mawlid Annabawi (national)
events.description: The birth of the Prophet Muhammad is celebrated every year in Morocco. During this day, families show their devotion to their faith through prayers and gather to share traditional meals in a festive atmosphere.

events.title: May 1: Labour Day (national)
events.description: Each year, Morocco celebrates Labour Day with a public holiday.

events.title: Ninth month of the Islamic calendar (dates change each year): Ramadan (celebrated nationwide)
events.description: Morocco celebrates the Islamic holy month of Ramadan, during which the Quran was revealed to the Prophet Muhammad. Fasting begins each day at sunrise and ends at sunset. For the entire month, Marrakech operates at a slower pace during the day and stirs into action at nightfall.

events.title: First day of the tenth month of the Islamic calendar (dates change each year): Eid al-Fitr (national holiday)
events.description: In Islamic tradition, this day marks the end of the fasting month of Ramadan and is a time for family celebrations and great feasts bringing together all family members.

events.title: July 30: Throne Day (national)
events.description: National celebration commemorating the enthronement of King Mohammed VI. Major festivities mark this holiday: parades, ceremonies, and official speeches and fireworks… The Moroccan metropolis is jubilant.

events.title: August 14: Feast of Oued Ed-Dahab (national)
events.description: This holiday marks the return of the Saharan provinces to Morocco in 1949.

events.title: August 20: Revolution of the King and the people (national)
events.description: A symbolic day recalling the deportation of King Mohammed V after his dismissal by the French authorities in 1953. Military parades, fireworks, and flags flying from the windows: Moroccans show the attachment they have for their King in a festive celebration.

events.title: August 21: Festival of Youth (national)
events.description: Moroccan youth are celebrated on the anniversary of the birth of Mohammed VI. Shows, dances, happenings: the children of Marrakech play joyfully in the streets of the city.

events.title: Tenth day of the last month of the Islamic calendar (date changes each year): Eid al-Adha (national holiday)
events.description: It is considered the most important of the yearly Muslim holidays and honours Ibrahim as a model for all believers. This is also an occasion for sumptuous family gatherings, for which it is recommended to multiply offerings and gifts.

events.title: November 6: Green March (national)
events.description: National Day inaugurated by Hassan II, commemorating the march of 350,000 Moroccans to the Spanish Sahara to which Morocco claimed possession.

events.title: November 18: Independence Day (national)
events.description: On this day of national celebration, Morocco celebrates the end of the French protectorate, which occurred in 1955.

administrativeProcedures.title: Entry requirements for Morocco
administrativeProcedures.description:
For a stay of less than three months in Morocco, it is necessary for French citizens to have a passport that remains valid throughout the entirety of the scheduled stay.

A passport is mandatory, including for tourist travel in organised groups.

If your stay is for more than three months, it is necessary to notify Moroccan immigration to demand an extension.

To enjoy peace of mind during your stay in Marrakech and Morocco, be sure to check with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in your home country for the latest travel information and recommendations. Comprehensive information that may be helpful for international visitors is also provided on the Morocco page of the French Ministry of Foreign Affairs' website: https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/en/country-files/morocco/

goodToKnow.title: Good to know

administration.title: GOVERMENT OFFICES
administration.openingHours: Usually open Monday to Friday from 8:00 a.m. until 4:15 p.m. (short operating time on Friday (prayer) and 9:15 a.m. to 2:00 p.m. during Ramadan)

banks.title: BANKS
banks.openingHours: Usually open Monday to Friday from 8:15 a.m. to 4 p.m. (from 9:15 a.m. to 2 p.m. during Ramadan)

goodToKnow.daylightSavingTime:
Daylight Savings Time start date: last Sunday in March
Daylight Savings Time end date: last Sunday in October
goodToKnow.tips:
Tipping
In Morocco, the tip is not included in the bill. It is therefore considered polite to leave a percentage for the service from 10 to 15% of the total bill. A tip to the housekeeping staff (maids, porters…) in hotels is appreciated.
